newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Asian stocks mixed, cautious over U.S. rates.
newsitem.headline: Asian stocks mixed, cautious over U.S. rates.

text.p: Hong Kong stocks rose on Friday and other Asian markets put in a mixed performance, with many participants still away and others looking to Wall Street for direction.
Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index closed 19.35 points or 0.15 percent higher at 13,222.79 after seesawing within a 100-point band.
"The market looks like it has stabilised," said Anthony Mak, associate director at Vickers Ballas. "But we could see it dip to 13,000 if there is further weakness on Wall Street."
Overnight the Dow Jones industrial index fell sharply in early trading but managed to cut losses by the close, ending down 5.78 points at 6,442.49.
Nervous investors fear recent data showing a robust economy could signal a resurgence of inflation, followed by higher interest rates that would undermine soaring share valuations.
The Tokyo market remained closed for holidays.

In Singapore, the key Straits Times Industrials Index ended up 7.29 points or 0.33 percent at 2,224.08. A dealer said there was renewed concern about a U.S. rate hike at the Federal Reserve's next Open Market Committee meeting on February 4-5.
"The Dow might be affected if there is any rate hike. So today's trade is dominated by a very cautious, wait-and-see attitude," the dealer said.
The Jakarta Composite index rose 8.09 points or 1.27 percent to close at 646.19 points.

Brokers said they had initially expected the market to remain slow, but a spurt of buying in stocks of large-capitalized companies in late trading boosted sentiment and prompted further buying in small-caps as well.

Thai stocks finished sharply lower for the third straight session as investors continued showing jitters about weak economic indicators and talk of loan defaults faced by financial institutions, brokers said.
The SET index ended 15.66 points or 1.95 percent lower at a near 52-month low of 787.47. The index last closed lower on September 9, 1992 at 782.85.
The Australian share market closed lower after a volatile Wall Street kept local investors nervous. The All Ordinaries index was 11.7 points or 0.49 percent lower at 2,399.5.
Crude oil futures fell in Asia. February Brent on SIMEX traded down to a low of $24.05, down 17 cents from London's settlement overnight.
Hong Kong gold ended down from the previous New York close. Bullion ended at US$365.00/50 an ounce against New York's US$365.25/75 close on Thursday.
At 1115 GMT the dollar was trading at 115.60/70 yen and 1.5473/78 marks.
